thread.title: Japan Set to Make History with Precision Lunar Landing
thread.title_full: Japan Set to Make History with Precision Lunar Landing

author: Wojciech Zylm
title: Japan Set to Make History with Precision Lunar Landing
text:
Jeffrey Gouweleeuw Commits to Augsburg: Contract Extended Until 2025
Japan Set to Make History with Precision Lunar Landing
In a significant leap for Japan’s space program, the nation is set to make history as the fifth country to land a spacecraft on the moon. The moon landing, scheduled for Friday, involves the Smart Lander for Investigating Moon (SLIM) probe. The endeavor, led by the Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency (JAXA), is designed to make a precise landing on the lunar surface.
The SLIM Mission
The SLIM project aims to examine rocks that are crucial for understanding the origins of the moon and Earth, potentially harnessing water resources for future lunar bases. The mission’s success would mark Japan’s entry into a new era of lunar exploration and commercialization. The SLIM probe is equipped with ‘vision-based navigation’ technology designed to land within 100 meters of its target. This technology bears crucial implications for future exploration of the moon’s poles as potential sources of oxygen, fuel, and water.
Setting New Standards
JAXA’s goal is to carry out more frequent missions in the future by reducing launch costs. The agency has several other lunar landers and exploration projects in the pipeline. The SLIM mission aims to be the most precise, using advanced technology and experience gained from JAXA’s previous missions. Success would position Japan as a key player in the conquest of the moon.
Revolutionizing Space Exploration
The SLIM spacecraft targets a landing site near the Sea of Tranquility, just south of where Apollo 11 landed in 1969. The mission’s objective is to study the composition of rocks and uncover the moon’s origins, a crucial step amid a renewed international push to explore the moon. The mission also includes the deployment of a robot, SORA Q, designed in collaboration with toy company, Takara Tomy. Known for its miniaturization and weight-saving expertise, the robot will rove the lunar surface, further contributing to space exploration and scientific research.
